Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2009 07:00AM zoohouse10 wrote: Hi Everyone, I did my 3rd TCH treatment yesterday.  Feel pretty good at this point. Pjkappel-  I too am working through the decision process of a Bilateral Mastectomy.  I am reading the Breast Reconstruction Guidebook.  Its a great book because is explains the process and all the options for reconstruction.  I bought my book from Amazon.com.  I am feeling more and more confident with my decision.  Its time to start making doctors appointments.  One of the hardest parts of making this decision is facing the recovery ahead after already going through the chemo.  I know exactly how you feel.  The more I think about it the more comfortable I come with it.  I have talked with a few ladies now regarding their experiences and they all have given me nothing but positive feedback.  I am a big chicken when it comes to surgeries so its tough putting yourself in that position voluntarily. So do your research and hang in there.  You will find your way through this maze and have a decision you will be comfortable with. Polly- hang in there.  your son will be back before you know it and you will be feeling better when he gets back.  Imagine how great that will be. Mary stay strong we are all praying for you. Take care - Diane

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 08:43AM zoohouse10 wrote: Mary Did you do a BrCAnaysis?  I had my done because I have so much Breast Cancer in my family.  I do have the genetic mutation on my BRCA2 gene.  I'm going to see a genetic counselor at the begining of July.  One of the things I am trying to decide on is if I'm want to do the bilateral mastectomy.  After my lumpectomy, I just don't know that I am up for that kind of surgery.  I know the peace of mind would be nice but I am on the fence if I want to do something that major.  I am hoping my appointment with the genetic counselor will help to sort out my risk factors.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 08:46PM zoohouse10 wrote: Someone mentioned thrush. I was told to eat yogurt.  My Onc Nurse said that the bacteria in yogurt is good for thrush. As far as hair loss, I was told by the sales people at the wig store that chemo goes after fast growing cells which is why the hair on your head goes.  But I was told eyebrows and eyelashes are not fast growing cells so they usually only thin out or don't go as all.  As far as arms and legs I don't have an answer because it seems that I am still having to shave but not as often. Polly first of all I am sending you a big hug.  I completely understand your anger and the courage it took to go to work today.  The realization that there is no turning back.  So at this point we need to just keep moving forward. I enjoy wearing my hat the most but I did wear my wig to work today.  It was a difficult to face everyone.  By the end of the day I was kind of used to it.  I will wear it at work but I think that will be it.   Polly hold your head up high.  I think this will get easier with each passing day.  I think we will fee more comfortable as time passes.  I say I think because I am literally walking down this path by your side.  But I am an optimist so my feeling is each day will get better. I am her2+ so I am taking herceptin.  I have 6 chemo treatments of TCH ( taxotere, carboplatin and herceptin).  I take the hercepting with the chemo every 3 weeks.  Once I am done with my 6 treatments my herceptin continues on every 3 weeks for an entire year. I think the protocol for her2+ is a little different on the west coast then on the east coast.  Anyways that is what I am doing. Enjoy your evening. Diane

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2009 02:30PM zoohouse10 wrote: Pdaw -  I ordered the Breast Reconstruction Guidebook by Kathy Steligo from Amazon.com.  It was about $13.50.  I am so sorry you are having such a touch week.  Wow, that is a lot to take in.  I hope you will be feeling better soon. Polly- I thought when you have a bilateral mastectomy you don't need radiation.  But every doctor is different. Gjlanders, I buzzed  my hair (leaving about 1/4 inch) on day 18 of my 1st tx because so much was falling out.  But I have alot of hair.  Anyways, I am now 17 days out from my 2nd tx and I still have alot of hair.  Its is thin but I just wish it would all fall out already.  Judging from everyone's posts, it seems like a crappy week for many of us.  The weekend is here, lets pick ourselves up and enjoy.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 07:28AM zoohouse10 wrote: Polly- after my first treatment I had a cough (after flying to Ohio).  Anyways they put me on antibiotics (2 courses).  When I came up for my 2nd treatment my blood was fine but they gave me the option to set my treatment back by a week because my cough was not totally gone.  I went ahead with treatment and my cough came back but not has bad.  I have had a mild cough thoughout my treatment.  Each treatment that I have it flares up but then it goes away in time for the next treatment.  I am hoping my next treatment that I will have hopefully kicked the cough.  Anyways Polly, I do continue my treatment even though I have a cough because I just want to get it done and I don't want anything to slow me down. Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 08:23AM zoohouse10 wrote: Diane 48: I get my neulasta shot in my arm and that is where the nurse gives it to me. Amlg1:  I experienced the exact same pain on Day 6 of my treatment.  I was flying home from Ohio (my son graduated from OSU) so I started to worry because I was in the airport and I was praying it wasn't going to get worse.  I took tylenol because that is all I had on me.  That helped and it was tolerable.  By the time I got home it was not bothering me.  YOu are probably right about it coming from the neulasta.  It was probably processing through your kidneys.  I had a similar reaction on my first chemo with the Taxotere and they told me it went right to my kidneys so we had to stop for a time and give me more decatron.  But I guess it's all par for the course. Bettina: I have found my discomfort with my "new cancer look"  has gotten better with each passing day.  I do wear a wig to work and am feeling better about it each day.  I wear a hat around home and get alot of compliments on my hat (I wear the "newsboy hat").  Greytmom17: Welcome to your new look.  I hope you adjust well.  I can be difficult at first but hang in there, it gets better. Susie:  I am surprised your wig stayed on through the night.  I had my wig on the other day at the doctors office and he did a breast exam and when I laid back,  I felt my wig slip up.  Thank goodness it didn't totally slip off. So I had my 2nd treatment yesterday and still on my decatron high but that will end tonight and the neulasta shot this afternoon.  So my not so great days are ahead. For all of you struggling with your hair loss I wish you a couragous day.  You are all beautiful so stay strong. Have a nice day Diane P.S.  Tom n Di  Where have you been.  Last we heard she had 0 WBC count.  Just hoping all is alright with her.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 07:50AM zoohouse10 wrote: I finally got the courage to buzz off my hair last night.  In May when I found out I would start Chemo in June (9th) and my hair would fall out I decided to stop dying my hair.  So when I buzzed off my hair, I had a double whammy, the short hair and it turns out there is so so much grey. Moral to the story: don't stop dying your hair.  Duh, you would think I could have figured that out. I just thought that all my hair would fall out so rapidly that I would be completely bald. So my questions are, will I go completely bald?  If so, how long does it take? If it takes a long time can I dye this very very very short hair I have left.   One more thing, if it takes a long time to come out, I would recommend a cute pixie for this phase. These are all of my questions after the fact.  I wish I would have thought of them before.   Chemo #2 is on Tuesday. Enjoy the day.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 10:22AM zoohouse10 wrote: Blessedby4, My Chemo treatments are TCH as well.  My first treatment was 6/9 and I am going for my 2nd on Tuesday. For me, the treatment day was long.  I had a reaction to the taxotere so it was extra long. I felt fine that night.  I was able to eat, no nausea. The next day I totally fine (still on steriods), this is the day most get the neulasta shot. After you finish your steriods and you have the neulasta shot, things start to spiral downward on day 2.  By the 3rd day I felt like I had the flu.  Very achy and sore from my head to my toes. No appetite.  If you can, that is a good day to try to sleep through.  I also found a vanilla shake and chicken noodle soup were my go to meals.  I soaked in the bath tub.  Whatevery makes you feel good on that day.  After that you will feel better each and everyday.  From that point you will experience all kinds of various side effects from loss of appetite, taste buds...nothing tastes right...nothing, headaches, hair loss (starting around day 15). By the time you get to week 3, I felt great except for the hair loss part. Most of the side effects are not debilitating, just annoying and serve as a daily reminder of what your are going through.  Truly I was only down for the count 1 day.  My biggest fear was nausea and that was not a problem.  You doctor will give a perscription for that to help you out. Many of the side effects, the ladies on the board have experienced and will be happy to share their remedies. Good luck tomorrow.  The first treatment is scary but you will see, its not that bad.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 10:51AM zoohouse10 wrote: Hi Ladies, I've been keepin up with everyone's post but I just haven't felt like writing.  I physically I have been feeling great.  My 3rd tx is on July 22nd so this is my good week.  I went to see a genetic counselor regarding my brca2 mutation.  I took a bunch of my family members as well to be tested and learn about what is going on in my family.  Since I am in the midst of my cancer treatment this all feels like water under the bridge for me, but for them, it was somewhat scary at the statistics are quite starling.  Anyways, at this point I have decided to have my ovaries removed (at age 44 fairly easy decision).  Its the bilateral matectomy that I am having trouble deciding on. Polly, I know you had the DIEP and I would love to hear your thoughts on the procedure.  Are you done with all of the surgeries? Are you happy with the results. Is there any one on this thread that has done the "One Step" with Alloderm implants.  I would love to hear your thoughts. I ordered the Breast Reconstruction Guidebook and hopefully I can be better informed to make this decision.  I know there are other threads on this message board that deal with this but I thought I would run it by the Junies since I feel more comfortable with you ladies. Good luck to all of you having chemo this week.  Hopefully everyones side effects will be minimal.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 11:55AM zoohouse10 wrote: Polly-  I am 44 and I have not had my period since I started my Chemo.  They told me I would not have my period during Chemo, and there was a possibility it would not return at the end, thereby throwing me into early menopause. So I am enjoying not having to deal with that too.  As far as early menopause, I have not had any hot flashes, night sweats etc.  So I am enjoying the vacation from my period. My sisters results for their genetic testing came back.  They were both negative. and I find myself strangely sad.  Not because they are negative but because I am the only one that was positive.  So I find myself asking...why me???  I feel strangely alone.  So I am in the midst of my own pity party.  I guess I need to stop asking why and start making some tough decisions.  I guess I'm just having a tough day. So Gjlanders, it does matter that you are fine and alive.  So keep your head up because there will be hills and valleys that we all will go through. btw,  I was feeling down because of all this genetic stuff.  I guess who was in my neighborhood yesterday filming....Cesar Millan.  I was so excited to meet him.  Both my daughter and I got to take a picture with him.  So sometimes there are unexpected positves to help with all the negative. Anyways, enjoy your day. Diane

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 08:25AM zoohouse10 wrote: Its been such a long time since I've written on the board.  But I have been quietly following everyone's progress.  I just couldn't get myself to write.  I finished my 6th chemo treatment and now I just continue on with herceptin every three weeks until June.  I hear it is a piece of cake compared to the the chemo so I am hopeful that this is true. I did my last chemo treatment on the 23rd so on Sunday when I crawled out of my hole I was so relieved that the worst was behind me.  Even though I am not 100% I was happy to know that I can start to put some of this behind me.  I have scheduled my bilateral mastectomy for 11/4 so I still have a big hurdle ahead of me but I am ready to face it. Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 08:35AM zoohouse10 wrote: Hi Ladies, It's been a while. I was trying to prepare for my bilateral mastectomy and so I just didn't have time to come on the board.  On 11/4 I had my mastectomy and all went well.  I am at home recovering for the next 3 weeks. Its nice to be home and not have anything to do but work on my recovery. Its been 9 days since surgery and I am feeling better and better each day.  I am pretty much off the pain killers.  I took one last night because I was really hurting.  I actually feel more uncomfortable from the swelling but even the swelling is starting to subside a bit. One thing I wanted to mention that I use and has helped me sleep is a neck rest (like the ones you use on an airplane.  I sleep propped up with a back rest and pillows.  The neck rest has helped to make me comfortable to sleep in this position.  I mention this because good sleep and rest is so important during recovery and this has helped me tremendously.  Just a tip for anyone going in to surgery. I continue getting my herceptin every 3 weeks and I haven't really noticed any side effects.  I think after the chemo the herceptin seems like a walk in the park. Anyways, I hope all if well with everyone. Diane
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee
